examples of phrasal verbs

A list compiled by Ingrid

back out (of sth)
  • hint Ingrid = withdraw one’s support
  • to decide that you are no longer going to take part in sth that has been agreed:
    • He lost confidence and backed out of the deal at the last minute
be st. out
  • hint Ingrid = be in error by 3 cms etc.

??

bear out
  • hint Ingrid = what sb. says
  • bear sb/sth ↔ out (especially BrE)
  • to show that sb is right or that sth is true
    • The other witnesses will bear me out
    • The other witnesses will bear out what I say
blow over
  • hint Ingrid = be soon forgotten
  • to go away without having a serious effect
    • The storm blew over in the night
    • The scandal will soon blow over
blow up
  • hint = an employee (for beeing late)
  • different usages
  1. blow up
    1. to explode: to be destroyed by an explosion:
      1. The bomb blew up
      2. A ploice officer was killed when his car blew up
    2. to start suddenly and with force:
      1. A storm was blowing up
      2. A crisis has blown up over the President’s latest speech
  2. blow sth ↔ up
    1. to destroy sth by an explosion
      1. The police station was blown up by terrorists
    2. to fill sth with air or gas so that it becomes firm
      1. The tyres (Reifen) on my bikes need blowing up
break off
  • (relations)
  • different usages
  1. break off
    1. to become seperated from sth. as a result of force
      1. The back section of the plane had broken off
    2. to stop speaking or stop doing sth for a time
      1. He broke off in the middle of a sentence
  2. break sth ↔ off
    1. to seperate sth, using force
      1. She broke off a piece of chocolate and gave it to me
    2. to end sth. suddenly:
      1. Britain threatened to break off diplomatic relations
      2. They’ve broken off their engagement
bring sth <-> about
  • hint: a change
  1. to make sth happen
  2. (SYN) CAUSE:
    1. What brouht about the change in his attitude
bring down
  • hint: a goverment
  • different usages
  1. bring sb ↔ down
    1. to make sb lose power or be defeated:
      1. The scandal my bring down the goverment
    2. (in football and rugby) to make sb fall over:
      1. He was brought down in penalty area
  2. to bring sth. down
    1. to lower or reduce sth:
      1. We aim to bring down prices on all computers
    2. to land an aircraft
      1. The pilot managed to bring down the plane down in a field

to make an aircraft fall out of the sky: Twelve enemy fighters had been brought down to make an animal or an bird fall down or fall out of the sky by killing or wound
